"If the pawn doesn't promote, I've always got a perpetual with the queen."
words.name: perpetual check

words.def: A move played to convince the opponent that their position is hopeless and they should resign. This could be an ostentatious sacrifice of a queen for a rook leaving an easily won pawn ending, or an unnecessary underpromotion.
words.name: persuader

words.def: An abbreviation for Portable Game Notation.
words.name: PGN

words.def: Usually refers to an important chess endgame which illustrates a drawing technique when the defender has a king and rook versus a king, rook, and pawn. It is also known as the third rank defence, because of the importance of the rook on the third rank cutting off the opposing king. It was analyzed by Philidor in 1777. See also Rook and pawn versus rook endgame.
words.name: Philidor position

words.def: One of the chessmen or figures used to play the game—king, queen, rook, bishop, knight or pawn. Each piece type has its own rules of movement on the board. The word "piece" can refer to any chess piece including pawns (as in the touched piece rule), or it can refer to a minor piece (as in "I hung a piece"), depending on context. It can also mean a major or minor piece, as in "White needs to get some pieces to the kingside."
words.name: piece

words.def: When a piece cannot move (either legally or advisedly) because doing so would expose a valuable piece, usually the king or queen, to attack. Pins against the king are called absolute because it is then illegal to move the pinned piece. Other pins are called relative pins.
words.name: pin

words.def: A strategy used by a chess player to make optimal use of his or her advantages in a specific position while minimizing the impact of his or her positional disadvantages.
words.name: plan

words.def: Said of an opening or move that gives the person playing it a tenable position, for example "Petroff's Defense is playable." or (after 1.e4 e5 2.Bc4 Nf6 3.Nc3 Nxe4 4.Nxe4) "4... d5 is the only playable move", implying that there are other legal moves, but they all leave the player in a worse position.
words.name: playable

words.def: an idiomatic expression meaning to make a move without analyzing the move.
words.name: play by hand

words.def: Term mainly used in computer chess to denote one play of either White or Black. Thus equal to half a move.
words.name: ply

words.def: An abbreviation for Portable Game Notation.
words.name: PGN

words.def: An unprotected pawn which, if captured, causes positional problems or material loss.
words.name: poisoned pawn

words.def: A variation of the Najdorf Variation of the Sicilian Defence, where some players call White's pawn on b2 a poisoned pawn since capturing it is dangerous for Black.
words.name: Poisoned Pawn Variation

words.def: This is a popular computer-processible ASCII format for recording chess games (both the moves and related data).
words.name: Portable Game Notation (PGN)

words.def: Play dominated by long-term maneuvering for advantage rather than by short-term attacks and threats, and requiring judgment more than extensive calculation of variations, as distinguished from tactics.
words.name: positional play

words.def: A player who specializes in positional play, as distinguished from a tactician.
words.name: positional player

words.def: A sacrifice in which the lost material is not regained via a combination, but instead gains positional compensation. These typically require deep positional understanding and are often overlooked by computers. Also known as a "true sacrifice", as opposed to a pseudo-sacrifice or sham sacrifice.
words.name: positional sacrifice

words.def: Analysis of a game after it has concluded, typically by one or both players and sometimes with spectators (kibitzers) contributing as well. A player who has just lost the game thanks to a dubious move will often win the post-mortem by finding a better one.
words.name: post-mortem

words.def: A well-analyzed novelty in the opening which is not published but first used against an opponent in competitive play.
words.name: prepared variation

words.def: A Russian term for simple strategic devices that depend on pawn structure.
words.name: priyome

words.def: An elegant and counterintuitive tactical shot, of the type generally found in chess problems rather than in actual play, can be termed problem-like.
words.name: problem-like

words.def: The Professional Chess Association (PCA) was a rival organisation to FIDE, the international chess organization. The PCA was created in 1993 by Garry Kasparov and Nigel Short for the marketing and organization of their chess world championship. The PCA lost its main sponsor, Intel, in 1996 and folded soon after.
words.name: Professional Chess Association (PCA)

words.def: Advancing a pawn to the eighth rank, converting it to a queen, rook, bishop or knight. Promotion to a piece other than a queen is called underpromotion.
words.name: promotion

words.def: [adjective: prophylactic] Prophylactic techniques include the blockade, overprotection, and the mysterious rook move.
words.name: prophylaxis

words.def: A passed pawn that is supported by another pawn.
words.name: protected passed pawn

words.def: See sham sacrifice.
words.name: pseudo-sacrifice

words.def: To move a pawn forward.
words.name: push

words.def: Symbol used for the queen when recording chess moves in English.
words.name: Q

words.def: The Queen's Gambit Accepted chess opening.
words.name: QGA

words.def: The Queen's Gambit Declined chess opening.
words.name: QGD

words.def: The Queen's Indian Defence chess opening.
words.name: QID

words.def: A round-robin style tournament between four players, where each participant plays every other participant once.
words.name: quad

words.def: 1.   see queen
words.name: queen

words.def: The bishop that was on the queenside at the start of the game. The terms queen knight and queen rook are also used. Sometimes abbreviated "QB", "QN", and "QR" respectively.
words.name: queen bishop (or queen's bishop)

words.def: A pawn on the queen's file, i.e. the d-file. Sometimes abbreviated "QP". Also queen rook pawn (QRP), queen knight pawn (QNP), and queen bishop pawn (QBP) for a pawn on the a-, b-, or c-file respectively.
words.name: queen pawn (or queen's pawn)

words.def: Promotion to a queen. Also called promotion. Rarely used to indicate promotion to a knight, rook, or bishop as well (underpromotion).
words.name: queening

words.def: The side of the board (board-half) the queens are on at the start of the game (the a- through d-file), as opposed to the kingside.
words.name: queenside (or queen's side)

words.def: Same as sudden death.
words.name: quickplay finish

words.def: A move that does not attack or capture an enemy piece.
words.name: quiet move

words.def: Symbol used for the rook when recording chess moves in English.
words.name: R

words.def: Another term for Harrwitz bishops.
words.name: raking bishops

words.def: A row of the chessboard. In algebraic notation, ranks are numbered 1–8 starting from White's side of the board; however, players customarily refer to ranks (but not files) from their own perspectives. For example: White's king and other pieces start on his or her first (or "back") rank, whereas Black calls the same rank the eighth rank; White's seventh rank is Black's second; and so on. If neither perspective is given, White's view is assumed. This relative reference to ranks was formalized in the older descriptive notation.
words.name: rank

words.def: A form of chess with reduced time limit, usually 30 minutes per player.
words.name: rapid chess (see fast chess)

words.def: To demonstrate that a strategy, move, or opening is not as good as previously thought (often, that it leads to a loss), or that previously published analysis is unsound. A refutation is sometimes colloquially referred to as a bust. A refutation in the context of chess problems or endgame studies is often called a cook.
words.name: refute

words.def: See corresponding squares.
words.name: related squares

words.def: A pin, where it is legal to move the pinned piece. See also absolute pin.
words.name: relative pin

words.def: A move a player has available. Such a move may not be crucial to the position on the board, but being able to force the opponent to move by making a reserve move can on occasion result in a significant advantage.
words.name: reserve tempo

words.def: To concede loss of the game. A resignation is usually indicated by stopping the clocks, and sometimes by offering a handshake or saying "I resign". The traditional way to resign is by tipping over one's king, but this is rarely done nowadays.[12] In master and serious amateur play, it is much more common for a game to be resigned than for it to end with checkmate, because experienced players can foresee checkmate well in advance.
words.name: resign

words.def: A player who in a hopeless position intentionally runs out of time to avoid having to resign can be said to have resigned on time. This is usually performed in a more subtle manner than that of Curt von Bardeleben walking out of the tournament hall against Wilhelm Steinitz. A player low on time and in a losing position may simply "forget" to pay any attention to the clock.
words.name: resign on time

words.def: Romantic chess was the style of chess prevalent in the 19th century. It is characterized by bold attacks and sacrifices.
words.name: Romantic chess

words.def: see rook
words.name: rook

words.def: A maneuver that places a rook in front of its own pawns, often on the third or fourth rank. This can allow the rook to treat a half-open file as if it were an open file, or a closed file as if it were half-open.
words.name: rook lift

words.def: A pawn on the rook's file, i.e. the a-file or h-file.
words.name: rook pawn

words.def: This is a tournament in which each participant plays every other participant an equal number of times, for example in the Hastings 1895 chess tournament. In a double round-robin tournament the participants play each other exactly twice, once with white and once with black, for example in the Piatigorsky Cup. A round robin tournament is commonly used if the number of participants is relatively small. See also Swiss tournament.
words.name: round-robin tournament

words.def: A fork between king and queen.
words.name: royal fork

words.def: 1.  A king or queen.
words.name: royal piece

words.def: Refers to unique attributes of the king: being subject to check and checkmate, the inability to be captured, and the ability to castle.
words.name: royal powers

words.def: Alternate notation for the knight piece. Used rather than the K, which is for king. From the German Springer [English: "jumper"].
words.name: S

words.def: Short for sacrifice, usually used to describe a sacrifice for a mating attack.
words.name: sac

words.def: A move or capture that voluntarily gives up material in return for an advantage such as space, development, or an attack. A sacrifice in the opening is called a gambit, especially when applied to a pawn.
words.name: sacrifice

words.def: An abbreviation for standard (or short) algebraic notation (e.g. 1.Nf3), as opposed to long algebraic notation (e.g. 1.Ng1-f3).
words.name: SAN

words.def: [from French] See blindfold chess.
words.name: sans voir

words.def: A four-move checkmate (common among novices) in which White plays 1.e4, follows with Qh5 (or Qf3) and Bc4, and finishes with 4.Qxf7#.
words.name: Scholar's Mate

words.def: A record of the moves of a particular game, usually expressed in algebraic notation.
words.name: score

words.def: The sheet of paper used to record a game in progress. During formal games, it is usual for both players to record the game using a score sheet. A completed score sheet contains the game score.
words.name: score sheet

words.def: Lengthy OTB games can be adjourned. To prevent unfair advantage, the players can agree on the next move being secretly recorded in a sealed envelope. Upon resumption, the arbiter makes the sealed move and the game continues. See also adjournment.
words.name: sealed move

words.def: An assistant hired to help a player in preparation for and during a major match or tournament. The second assists in areas such as opening preparation.[13] The second assisted with adjournment analysis, before the practice of adjournments was abandoned in the 1990s.
words.name: second

words.def: The expression "the second player" is sometimes used to refer to Black.
words.name: second player

words.def: See windmill.
words.name: seesaw

words.def: A chess opening that begins with White playing 1.d4 and Black replying with a move other than 1...d5. See also open game and closed game.
words.name: semi-closed game

words.def: A chess opening that begins with White playing 1.e4 and Black replying with a move other than 1...e5. Also called half-open or asymmetrical king pawn openings. See also open game and closed game.
words.name: semi-open game

words.def: An offer of material which is made at no risk, as acceptance would lead to the gain of equal or greater material or checkmate. This is in contrast to a true sacrifice in which the compensation is less tangible. Also called a pseudo-sacrifice.
words.name: sham sacrifice

words.def: Risky, double-edged, highly tactical. Sharp can be used to describe moves, maneuvers, positions, and styles of play.
words.name: sharp

words.def: Slang for an unexpected or sharp move that typically makes a tactical threat or technical challenge for the opponent.
words.name: shot

words.def: A strategy of exchanging pieces of equal value. Simplification can be used defensively to reduce the size of an attacking force. It can also be used by a player with an advantage to amplify that advantage or reduce the opponent's counterplay. Simplification is also used as an attempt to obtain a draw, or as an attempt to gain an advantage by players who are strong in endgame play with simplified positions. Also liquidation and trading.
words.name: simplification

words.def: A form of chess in which one (usually expert) player plays against several (usually novice) players simultaneously. Is often an exhibition.
words.name: simultaneous chess

words.def: An attack to a valuable piece, compelling it to move to avoid capture and thus exposing a less valuable piece which can then be taken.
words.name: skewer

words.def: A casual or "pickup" game, usually played without a chess clock. At chess tournaments, a skittles room is where one goes to play for fun while waiting for the next formal game.
words.name: skittles

words.def: A checkmate delivered by a knight in which the mated king is unable to move owing to it being surrounded (or smothered) by its own pieces. This could occur, for example, after 1.e4 Nc6 2.Ne2 Ne5, and now either 3.c3?? Nd3# or 3.g3?? Nf3#. Smothered mate is often achieved by sacrificing the queen.
words.name: smothered mate

words.def: In the tournament played by Sofia rules, players are not allowed to draw by agreement. They could have draws by stalemate, threefold repetition, fifty-move rule, or insufficient material. Other draws are allowed only if the arbiter declares the game reached a drawn position.
words.name: Sofia rules

words.def: An adjective used to describe a move, opening, or manner of play that is characterized by minimal risk-taking and emphasis on quiet positional play rather than wild tactics.
words.name: solid

words.def: Correct. A sound sacrifice has sufficient compensation, a sound chess opening or variation has no known refutation, and a sound composition has no cooks.
words.name: sound

words.def: A queen development in front of its own pawns, often early in the opening, usually for the purpose of exploiting an advantage in space or punishing an error by the opponent. So called because the queen is usually developed behind its own pawns for its protection. See flashing the queen.
words.name: sortie

words.def: The squares controlled by a player. A player controlling more squares than the other is said to have a spatial advantage. Effectively means much the same as mobility.
words.name: space

words.def: A white king bishop developed to b5. This is characteristic of the Ruy Lopez, also known as the Spanish Opening.
words.name: Spanish bishop

words.def: See Blitz chess.
words.name: speed chess

words.def: A harmless check given by a player who is about to be checkmated that serves no purpose other than to momentarily delay the defeat.
words.name: spite check

words.def: 1.  Gradually increasing the pressure of a bind.
words.name: squeeze

words.def: A position in which the player whose turn it is to move has no legal move and his or her king is not in check. A stalemate results in an immediate draw.
words.name: stalemate

words.def: The standard design of chess pieces, required for use in competition.
words.name: Staunton chess set

words.def: A stem game is the chess game featuring the first use of a particular opening variation. Sometimes, the player or the venue of the stem game is then used to refer to that opening.
words.name: stem game

words.def: Win characterised by gradual accumulation of advantages and complete prevention of counterplay.
words.name: strategic crush

words.def: Evaluation of game positions and setting up goals and longer-term plans for future play, as opposed to a tactic which is a shorter-term plan typically consisting of a well-defined sequence of moves and their contingent moves from a given game position.
words.name: strategy

words.def: A forceful or good move, a position having good winning chances, a highly rated player or one successful in tournaments, or a tournament having a sizable number of strong players competing, such as grandmasters. A "strong showing" refers to a player's high win ratio in a tournament. Opposite of weakness /weak, for example, a weak square.
words.name: strength (or strong)

words.def: 1.  The stronger side is the side with a material or positional advantage.
words.name: stronger side

words.def: 1.  A "strongpoint defense" means an opening which defends and retains a central pawn (White: e4 or d4; Black: e5 or d5), as opposed to exchanging the pawn and relinquishing occupation of that central square.
words.name: strongpoint

words.def: The most straightforward time control for a chess game: each player has a fixed amount of time available to make all moves. See also Fast chess.
words.name: sudden death

words.def: 1.  A ruse by which a player in a losing position tricks his or her opponent, and thereby achieves a win or draw instead of the expected loss. See also cheapo.
words.name: swindle

words.def: This is a tournament that uses the Swiss system to determine player pairings. The basic idea is that every round each player is paired with an opponent with the same (or close to the same) score. The 33rd Chess Olympiad is an example of a Swiss tournament. See also round-robin tournament.
words.name: Swiss tournament (see Swiss-system tournament)

words.def: A symmetrical position on the chessboard means the positions of one's pieces are exactly mirrored by the opponent's pieces. This most often occurs when Black mimics White's opening moves. Black is said to break symmetry when he or she makes a move no longer imitating White's move.
words.name: symmetry

words.def: from Arabic طبيعة ṭabīʕa, "normal manner"
words.name: tabia (or tabiya)

words.def: See endgame tablebase.
words.name: tablebase

words.def: A player who specializes in tactical play, as distinguished from a positional player.
words.name: tactician

words.def: Play characterized by short-term attacks and threats, often requiring extensive calculation by the players, as distinguished from positional play.
words.name: tactics

words.def: Used in casual games whereby both players agree to undo one or more moves.
words.name: takeback

words.def: Named after Siegbert Tarrasch, this refers to the general principle that rooks usually should be placed behind passed pawns, either one's own or one's opponent's.
words.name: Tarrasch rule

words.def: As abbreviation for tournament director.
words.name: TD

words.def: The manner in which a player converts an advantageous position into a win.
words.name: technique

words.def: An extra move, an initiative at development. A player gains a tempo (usually in the opening) by making the opponent move the same piece twice or defend an enemy piece. In the endgame, one may wish to lose a tempo by triangulation to gain the opposition. (Plural: tempos or tempi.)
words.name: tempo

words.def: A position in which there are one or more exchanges possible, such as a pair of pawns facing each other on a diagonal where either can capture the other, is said to contain tension. Such a situation differs from a threat in that it does not need to be immediately resolved – for example, if both pawns are defended. The consequences of resolving the tension must be constantly considered by both players, in case there is a possibility of winning or losing material. This makes calculating the best move more complicated, and so there is a natural temptation to release the tension by making a like-for-like exchange (see simplification) or by moving the attacked piece. To keep the tension is to avoid resolving it, which is sometimes good advice depending on the position.
words.name: tension

words.def: This term is used in written analysis of chess games to refer to a move actually played in the game as opposed to other possible moves. Can be shortened to "text", for example "The text is inferior as it allows ...f5". Text moves are usually in bold whereas analysis moves are not.
words.name: text move

words.def: A move or plan suited to the demands of the position. Most openings have well-known thematic moves associated with them, for example Black's ...c5 in the [French Defence]] is a thematic move, whereas blocking the c-pawn with ...Nc6 would be unthematic. Moves may be thematic but still bad due to their inferior timing, or unthematic but still good due to a quirk of the position.
words.name: thematic

words.def: A chess tournament in which every game must begin with a particular chess opening specified by the organizers, for example the Budapest Gambit (1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e5).
words.name: theme tournament

words.def: A new move in an opening. Also called simply a novelty.
words.name: theoretical novelty (TN)

words.def: A plan or move that, if left unattended, would result in an immediate depreciation of the opponent's position.
words.name: threat

words.def: A draw may be claimed if the same position occurs three times with the same player to move, and with each player having the same set of legal moves each time (the latter includes the right to take en passant and the right to castle).
words.name: threefold repetition

words.def: This refers to a number of different systems that are used to break ties, and thus designate a single winner, where multiple players or teams tie for the same place in a Swiss system chess tournament.
words.name: tiebreaks (see tie-breaking in Swiss-system tournaments)

words.def: Opportunities to make moves: similar meaning to tempo. A move that does not alter the position significantly is described as "wasting time", and forcing the other player to waste time is described as "gaining time".
words.name: time

words.def: The allowed time to finish a game, usually measured by a chess clock. A time control can require either a certain number of moves be made per time period (e.g., 40 moves in 2½ hours) or it can limit the length of the entire game (e.g., 5 minutes per game for blitz). Hybrid schemes are used, and time delay controls have become popular since the widespread use of digital clocks.
words.name: time control

words.def: A time control which makes it possible for a player to avoid having an ever-decreasing amount of time remaining (as is the case with sudden death). The most important time delays in chess are Bronstein delay and Fischer delay.
words.name: time delay

words.def: Having very little time on one's clock (especially less than five minutes) to complete one's remaining moves. See time control.
words.name: time pressure (or time trouble)

words.def: An abbreviation for theoretical novelty.
words.name: TN

words.def: In team chess, the player who is assigned to face the strongest opponents. Also called first board. Second board faces the next strongest players, followed by third board, and so on. Generally board assignments must be made before the competition begins and players may not switch boards, although reserve players are often allowed as substitutes.
words.name: top board

words.def: Slang for promotion.
words.name: touchdown

words.def: The rule requiring a player who touches a piece that has at least one legal move to move that piece (and, if the player moves the piece to a particular square and takes his or her hand off it, to move it to that square). Castling must be initiated by moving the king first, so a player who touches his or her rook may be required to move it, without castling. The rule also requires a player who touches an opponent's piece to capture it if possible. A player wishing to touch a piece to adjust its position on a square without being required to move it signals this intent by saying "J'adoube" or "I adjust". This way of playing is common in official games, in favour of clock move.
words.name: touched piece rule (or touch-move rule)

words.def: A competition involving more than two players or teams, generally played at a single venue (or series of venues) in a relatively short period of time. A tournament is divided into rounds, with each round consisting either of individual games or matches in the case of knockout tournaments and team tournaments. The assignment of opponents is called pairing, with the most popular systems being round-robin and Swiss. Tournaments are usually referred to by combining the city in which they were played with the year, as in "London 1851", although there are well-known exceptions, such as "AVRO 1938".
words.name: tournament

words.def: A book recording the scores of all the games in a tournament, usually with analysis of the best or most important games and some background on the event and its participants. One well-known example is Bronstein's Zurich International Chess Tournament 1953. The less comprehensive tournament bulletin is usually issued between the rounds of a prestigious event, giving the players and world media an instant record of the games of the previous round. Individual copies may be bundled together at the conclusion of the event to provide an inexpensive alternative to the tournament book.
words.name: tournament book

words.def: Organizer and arbiter of a tournament, responsible for enforcing the tournament rules and the Laws of Chess. Also tournament controller [chiefly British].
words.name: tournament director (TD)

words.def: See exchange.
words.name: trade

words.def: To reach a position by transposition.
words.name: transition

words.def: Arriving at a position using a different sequence of moves.
words.name: transposition

words.def: A move which may tempt the opponent to play a losing move. See also swindle.
words.name: trap

words.def: A position of mutual zugzwang in which either player would lose if it is their turn to move.
words.name: trébuchet

words.def: A technique used in king and pawn endgames (less commonly seen with other pieces) to lose a tempo and gain the opposition.
words.name: triangulation

words.def: Three pawns of the same color on the same file; generally considered a weakness due to their inability to defend each other.
words.name: tripled pawns

words.def: Endgame analysis by Alexey Troitsky of two knights versus a pawn found certain pawn positions that result in win, draw or loss. The resulting pawn positions on each file form what is known as the Troitsky line or Troitsky position.
words.name: Troitsky line (or Troitzky line)

words.def: Synonym for bishop pair.
words.name: two bishops (or The two bishops)

words.def: This is a chess tactic (also known as removal of the guard) in which a defensive piece is captured, leaving one of the opponent's pieces undefended or underdefended.
words.name: undermining

words.def: Promoting a pawn to a rook, bishop, or knight instead of a queen. Rarely seen unless the knight can deliver a crucial check, or when promotion to a rook or a bishop instead of a queen is necessary to avoid stalemate.
words.name: underpromotion

words.def: This is a nonprofit organization, the governing chess organization within the United States, and one of the federations of the FIDE.
words.name: United States Chess Federation (USCF)

words.def: See irregular opening.
words.name: unorthodox opening

words.def: The act of breaking a pin by interposing a second piece between the attacker and the target. This allows the piece that was formerly pinned to move.
words.name: unpinning

words.def: A positive term; to get out of a cramped or otherwise awkward position without suffering any disadvantage. Often this awkward position is the result of a gambit by the opponent, and so a player who unravels successfully can look forward to an endgame advantage thanks to their extra material.
words.name: unravel

words.def: Antonym of sound.
words.name: unsound

words.def: An abbreviation for the United States Chess Federation.
words.name: USCF

words.def: A sacrifice made for the purpose of clearing a square for a different piece of the same color.
words.name: vacating sacrifice

words.def: A player who exchanges a large number of pieces without consideration for their position is simply "vacuum cleaning" the board. "Getting the vacuum cleaner out" can be thought of as an extreme form of simplification, which is often a useful strategy.
words.name: vacuum cleaner

words.def: A move which opens one line and closes another.
words.name: valve

words.def: See chess variant.
words.name: variant

words.def: 1.  A sequence of moves or an alternative line of play, often applied to the opening. A variation does not have to have been played in a game, it may also be a possibility that occurs only in analysis.
words.name: variation

words.def: See file.
words.name: vertical line

words.def: 1.  A passive but harmless move played while waiting for initiative from the opponent.
words.name: waiting move

words.def: An abbreviation for the World Chess Championship.
words.name: WCC

words.def: A square that cannot be easily defended from attack by an opponent. Often a weak square is unable to be defended by pawns (a hole) and can be theoretically occupied by a piece. Exchange or loss of a bishop may make all squares of that bishop's color weak resulting in a "weak square complex" on the light squares or the dark squares.
words.name: weak square

words.def: An abbreviation for the Woman FIDE Master title.
words.name: WFM

words.def: An abbreviation for the Woman Grandmaster title.
words.name: WGM

words.def: The light-colored squares on the chessboard are often referred to as "the white squares" even though they often are some other light color. Similarly, "the white pieces" are sometimes actually some other (usually light) color. See also black.
words.name: white

words.def: The designation for the player who moves first, even though the corresponding pieces, referred to as "the white pieces", are sometimes actually some other (usually light) color. See also Black and first-move advantage.
words.name: White (see White and Black in chess)

words.def: An extremely unclear or complicated position or move.
words.name: wild

words.def: An abbreviation for the Woman International Master title.
words.name: WIM

words.def: 1.  A victory for one of the two players in a game, which may occur due to checkmate, resignation by the other player, the other player exceeding the time control, or the other player being forfeited by the tournament director. Chess being a zero-sum game, this results in a loss for the other player. An exception is a win as a result of a tournament bye.
words.name: win

words.def: A combination in which two pieces work together to deliver an alternating series of checks and discovered checks in such a way that the opposing king is required to move on each turn. It is a potent technique since on every other move, the discovered check may allow the non-checking piece to capture an enemy piece without losing a tempo. The most famous example is Torre–Lasker, Moscow 1925. Also called a seesaw.
words.name: windmill

words.def: The queenside a-, b-, and c-file, or the kingside f-, g-, and h-file. Also called flank.
words.name: wing

words.def: The name given to variations of several openings in which one player gambits a wing pawn, usually the b-pawn.
words.name: Wing Gambit

words.def: The FIDE chess rules describe that "The game is draw when a position is reached from which a checkmate cannot occur by any possible series of legal moves" (FIDE rule 9.6).
words.name: winning material

words.def: A number calculated by taking the percentage of games won by a player plus half the percentage of drawn games. Thus, if out of 100 games a player wins 40, draws 32, and loses 28, her winning percentage is 40 plus half of 32, i.e. 56 percent.
words.name: winning percentage

words.def: A position is said to be a winning if one specified side, with correct play, can eventually force a checkmate against any defence (i.e. perfect defence). Also called a won game.
words.name: winning position

words.def: A women-only chess title ranking below Woman International Master.
words.name: Woman FIDE Master (WFM)

words.def: The highest ranking gender-restricted chess title except for Women's World Champion.
words.name: Woman Grandmaster (WGM)

words.def: A women-only chess title ranking below Woman Grandmaster and above Woman FIDE Master.
words.name: Woman International Master (WIM)

words.def: See winning position.
words.name: won game

words.def: Slang for pieces. "A lot of wood came off the board" conveys that several piece exchanges occurred.
words.name: wood

words.def: A weak chess player, also referred to as a patzer or duffer. Colloquial, typically intended as criticism.
words.name: woodpusher

words.def: A winner of the World Chess Championship.
words.name: World Champion

words.def: See wrong rook pawn.
words.name: wrong-colored bishop (or wrong bishop)

words.def: With a bishop, a rook pawn may be the wrong rook pawn, depending on whether or not the bishop controls its promotion square.
words.name: wrong rook pawn

words.def: 1.  An attack upon two pieces in a line, similar to a pin, synonymous with skewer.
words.name: x-ray

words.def: [German, "time crisis"] Having very little time on the clock to complete the remaining moves of a timed game. Synonymous with time pressure and "time trouble".
words.name: zeitnot

words.def: Tournaments organised by FIDE, the first qualifying cycle of the World Chess Championship. Each zonal tournament features top players of a certain geographical zone. Up until 1993 the winners went on to Interzonal tournaments. This was replaced by a system where the winners now play each other in knockout-style competitions to determine who goes on to the Candidates Tournament.
words.name: Zonal tournaments

words.def: [German, "compulsion to move"] When a player is put at a disadvantage by having to make a move; where any legal move weakens the position. Zugzwang usually occurs in the endgame, and rarely in the middlegame.
words.name: zugzwang

words.def: [German, "in between check"] A zwischenzug that is a check.
words.name: zwischenschach

words.def: [German, "inbetween move"] An "inbetween" move played before the expected reply. In general, this involves responding to a threat by posing an even bigger threat to the opponent, forcing him to respond to the threat first.
words.name: zwischenzug
